title: How are citing literature and references different? - Quora

response.answer_text: How are citing literature and references different? -' Citing is a specific form of reference. A citation may quote or paraphrase and attribute. A reference need merely … uhhh … name the source and needn't even be specific. Citation vs reference (respectively): “To be or not to be …”, Hamlet, Act III, Wm. Shakespeare.As Shakespeare wrote, the choice to go on can be a stark decision.

The source of the information or ideas must be credited directly in the text and this is known as citing literature. Usually, the sources you cite will be your primary articles, popular article, books or texts. However, you should also cite any personal communications with researchers or instructors. Reference:Reference is a relationship between objects in which one object designates, or acts as a means by which to connect to or link to, another object. ... It is called a name for the second object. The second object, the one to which the first object refers, is called the referent of the first object.
